metadata.case_name: Anakapalla Co-operative Agricultural Industrial Society v. Its Workmen

facts.text: Industrial dispute between appellant and respondents (workmen) referred by Governor of Andhra Pradesh to Industrial Tribunal, Hyderabad under s. 10(1)(d) on December 7, 1960.
Vizagapatnam Sugar and Refinery Ltd. (Company) manufactured sugar but faced losses due to insufficient sugarcane supply.
Company attempted to shift business to Yerravaram but failed due to local cane growers who formed appellant Society to purchase the concern.

Sale transaction between Company and appellant completed on October 7, 1959. Agreement provided Company to pay retrenchment compensation and terminate services, leaving appellant free to choose employees.
Company paid Rs. 1,90,000 as retrenchment compensation to employees.
Employees' Union suggested purchasing concern or crediting compensation to Society, but not accepted.
Company had 800 workmen: 329 permanent, 471 seasonal. Appellant employed 678: 248 permanent (220 from Company, 28 new), rest seasonal. 49 permanent and 103 seasonal from Company not absorbed.
Appellant disputed claim: (1) not industrial dispute as sponsoring union (Thummapala Sugar Workers Union) not representative; (2) not successor-in-interest; (3) full complement employed.

Tribunal held sponsoring union competent, appellant successor-in-interest, ordered re-employment of 49 permanent (replacing new hires, rest on vacancies), similar for seasonal, with continuity and 1/4 back wages.
Sale agreement: Appellant did not take land, investments (Rs.19 lakhs), liabilities (Rs.27 lakhs), 4000 bags sugar, goodwill; Company to handle employee claims.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant is a successor-in-interest of the Company.
Scope and effect of s. 25-FF of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, particularly whether workmen entitled to re-employment by transferee or only compensation.
Whether the reference was competent as an industrial dispute.

petitioner_arguments.text: Dispute not industrial as sponsoring union not representative (bulk ex-employees, not current).
Not successor-in-interest as did not purchase entire concern, goodwill, took no liabilities, left assets with Company (sale agreement clauses).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Ramjilal Nathual v. Himabhai Mills Co. Ltd.; Antony D'Souza v. Sri Motichand Silk Mills

petitioner_arguments.text: Full complement of labour employed, no scope for re-employment.
Under s.25-FF, only compensation payable by transferor, no re-employment claim against transferee.

respondent_arguments.text: Entitled to re-employment as appellant is successor-in-interest.
s.25-H applies for re-employment priority; identity of undertaking matters, not employer.

court_reasoning.text: Sponsoring union competent to raise dispute.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tribunal correctly rejected invalidity of reference.

court_reasoning.text: Successor-in-interest determined by relevant factors: whole business? going concern? same place/business? no substantial break? goodwill? etc. Substance over form.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant is successor-in-interest: same business/place, no appreciable break, formed by local growers to continue.

court_reasoning.text: Pre-1956 adjudication balanced re-employment on fair play; s.25-FF (as amended post-Hariprasad) mandates compensation as if retrenched by transferor, no re-employment by transferee unless proviso applies.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Termination on transfer entitles to notice/compensation per s.25-F 'as if' retrenched; no double benefit of compensation + re-employment.

court_reasoning.text: s.25-H inapplicable as transfer termination not 'retrenchment' per s.2(oo) and Hariprasad.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinction via 'as if'; no continuity claim against transferee.

holdings.text: Under s.25-FF, workmen entitled only to compensation from transferor (Company), not re-employment by transferee (appellant).

precedents_cited.case_name: Ramjilal Nathual v. Himabhai Mills Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: First transfer not successor as not going concern, no liabilities; second was with goodwill.

precedents_cited.case_name: New Gujarat Cotton Mills Ltd. v. Labour Tribunal
precedents_cited.relevance: No interference with findings on successor-in-interest.

precedents_cited.case_name: Antony D'Souza v. Sri Motichand Silk Mills
precedents_cited.relevance: Purchaser not successor as only plant/machinery, not going concern; based on workmen document.

precedents_cited.case_name: Workmen of Dahingeapara Tea Estate v. Dahingeapara Tea Estate
Keys Constructions Co. Pvt. Ltd. v. Its Workmen
Hariprasad Shivshankar Shukla v. A. Divikar
precedents_cited.relevance: Retrenchment excludes closure/transfer; led to s.25-FF amendment.

precedents_cited.case_name: M/s. Hatisingh Manufacturing Co. Ltd. v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: 'As if' in s.25-FF distinguishes from actual retrenchment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Indian Hume Pipe Co. Ltd. v. The Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Retrenchment compensation for unemployment tide-over, not gratuity.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: s.25-FF governs transfer: compensation as if retrenched by transferor unless proviso; no re-employment by transferee. s.25-H inapplicable.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed, Tribunal's award set aside. Workmen not entitled to re-employment by appellant; only to compensation already paid by Company under s.25-FF.

key_quotes.text: The decision of the question must ultimately depend upon the evaluation of all the relevant factors and it cannot be reached by treating any one of them as of over-riding or conclusive significance.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Test for successor-in-interest: multi-factor, substance over form.

key_quotes.text: Workmen shall be entitled to notice and compensation in accordance with the provisions of s. 25-F, as if the workman had been retrenched.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: s.25-FF limits remedy to compensation from transferor.

key_quotes.text: This double benefit in the form of payment of compensation and immediate re-employment cannot be said to be based on any considerations of fair play or justice.
key_quotes.speaker: court
